Ukrainian war: global energy crisis

Oil prices are falling as the UAE supports increased supply

Blog post by Gaspard Vandenbulcke - Published at 10/03/2022, 10:22:16

Oil prices have fallen sharply after the United Arab Emirates (UAE) stated that it supports increased production.

Brent crude, a global benchmark, plunged more than 17% at one point after the UAE, a member of the influential oil cartel Opec, made its announcement.

The drop comes after weeks of price spikes fuelled by expectations of supply shortages resulting from Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

<hr />

Families all throughout the world are feeling the pinch as a result of increased prices.

President Joe Biden and other officials have promised to work to reduce consumer price pressures. Officials from the United States have been in contact with oil producers in order to increase supplies.

In a statement issued by the UAE Embassy in Washington, Ambassador Yousuf Al Otaiba said, "We favour production increases and will be encouraging Opec to consider higher production levels".

For more than a year, energy costs have been rising due to a quick increase in oil consumption, which had plummeted during the pandemic.

Is the world capable of surviving without Russian oil and gas?


Russia's invasion of Ukraine has added to pricing pressures, since sanctions make it difficult for the country, which produces around 7% of world oil supplies, to find clients.

The United States and Canada have both imposed prohibitions on Russian oil imports, while the United Kingdom has stated that it will phase out the bans by the end of the year.

Oil prices have risen by more than 30% since February 24, reaching $139 (Â£105) this week before reversing. In US trade, oil prices fell by roughly 12% to over $112 per barrel.

Brent crude rose in Asia trade to approximately $115 per barrel by lunchtime on Thursday.

The International Energy Agency (IEA) has decided to release 60 million barrels of oil from strategic national reserves, but this is insufficient to counteract recent price increases.

On Wednesday, the agency indicated that oil reserves may be tapped further.
